162049359.review:
This game is brilliant in many ways, but not for the gameplay. 

First lets start of with whats genuinely good about the game right now:
- amazing soundtracks
- a lot of weapon diversity and playstyle chosing
- lots of route finding
- a LOT of random stuff in the overworld giving rewards (its also a con cause of missing semi important items for builds is VERY probable)
-  well written story and Lore for everything in the verse right now
- good ending choices that have a deeper meaning for the players decision


Now lets go to the bad aspects that I found out from my gameplay so far (started Farum Azula  and completed everything else before it + Haligtree) :

- Middle and Endgame have LOTS of tedious stuff not out of difficulty but out of pure frustration => less fun in the endgame with the most amazing bosses in the game (Malenia, Morgott, ect.)
-  The scaling for the different areas is inconsistent. You're supposed to do Calid before Altus and Leyndell, yet the enemies there are a LOT stronger than the ones in Altus
- build options are hidden throughout the game and thus make respec-ing into another more favorable built of yours a necessity, which is not a good design with limited respecs
- the Arenas are genuinely the worst ones in any Fromsoft game like genuinely
- movement feels clunky due to target locking, making the rather weird option of free camming the better feel, but also significantly more harder for the average player who doesnt play claw
-  player level scaling is not intuitive. "What level am I supposed to be?" in areas with Vigor checks and also high density of enemies happenes countless times throughout the gameplay and the fact that you HAVE to be at a point in Vig. where 2 Flasks dont even full heal you... lets just say that doesnt help the feeling a player has
- broken weapons and limited uses till Farum Azula due to limited (somber) smith stones => cant pivot to other weapons for a LONG time 
- parrys feel awful on some enemies, especially Malenia. I genuinely enjoy parrys in general, but when the timing for parrys isnt the same across the board, why am I even supposed to play with shields in this game and not just go a dex/strength build or mega prepare a Intellligence built, it just doesnt make any sense to have a skill expression like that in the game when it isnt across the board and you need to literally relearn it for a majority of enemies
- a lot of repetitiveness in Bosses, Catacombs/graves, normal enemies, heck even weapons and spells
- unnecessary pacouring with the worst movement controls of any game I have played


In short: I am not a fan of how this game feels to play, how it makes the play have to REALLY think on what build to go, how to prepare (if at all) for bigger Bosses and what to expect from enemies around the boss. Very unfun and useless parts keep appearing in this game as is and give the player a miniscule reward in most cases and at best 15min of wandering in an area trying to figure out a "puzzle" (hint: its a dark tunnel or an invisible wall).

Love everything else about the game BESIDES the gameplay and thats why I cannot recommend this game for majority of players who want a good time, want to enjoy a chill game where they have a challenge but get rewarded. This game is none of these and is just a pure headache for anyone not taking it seriously.
No clue how this won GOTY honestly, I do have high hopes for the DLC though in terms of fixing problems.

162042056.review:
FromSoftware's formula makes for a unique experience when combined with a truly open world. While the end result is imperfect (the second half of the game is noticeably worse than the first in terms of enemy variety, rewarding exploration, and difficulty that inspires a sense of accomplishment instead of just relief when you overcome it), this might still be one of the overall best action RPGs in recent memory.

Elden Ring is also by far the most accessible game FromSoftware has ever made on account of things like spirit summons that can trivialize most bosses and the ability to overlevel a lot of content you find difficult by simply exploring instead of grinding. So, if you're looking for an entry point into soulslikes, look no further. If all else fails, you can always fall back on multiplayer co-op to overcome the game's most ludicrous challenges.

162018598.review:
While clearly not the worst From Software game, it's by far the most overrated. You can ignore the fact that most dungeons are the same dungeon copy-pasted or, in general, how much the same assets are re-used over and over. That is nearly inevitable in an open-world game.
But you cannot ignore the fact that you are not free to explore the world without risking of soft-locking most of the sub-quests (which the game gives no indication whatsoever) or without risking of overleveling.
But the worst offender in this game are the boss fights: really bad designed. They are hard but not challenging; it does not matter how good you are, if your character is not one of the meta builds you cannot defeat most of the main bosses. And no, being forced to follow a meta is not good game design (yes, even Let Me Solo Her is a meta build). Another very big problem with boss (and mid boss) fights is the spectacularization over gameplay. Most of the time you are forced to watch the boss doing all its acrobatics maneuvers while rolling away (yeah, shields don't really matters anymore), waiting, waiting and waiting for a split second window of opportunity to strike back, all while fighting against a camera view not intended for such choreography.
We are far away from the tactical and metodical fighting mechanic of Dark Souls. This is an extremely disappointing game.

161995909.review:
ELDEN RIIIING OH ELDEN RIIIIING
 To keep it short, this game is basically the culmination of Fromsoft's experience with "Soulsborne" as a whole, particularly improving on Dark Souls 3. 
It's easily the most accessible souls game thus far, with it being open world, and having a "play it at your own pace" attitude, as well providing tons of get out of jail free cards for newbies; from spirit ash summons to weapons that are broken OP in PvE, such as the "Rivers of Blood" Katana or the "Blasphemous Blade" greatsword, or even assistance in the form of online co-op with a buddy. As such, ER can simultaneously be the most difficult souls game ever, OR the easiest souls game ever, depending on how much you want to take advantage of these tools. At the very least, I'm proud of myself for managing to beat the main story as a STR build without using any spirit ashes as per me being a souls veteran, but again, it was purely my choice; mimic tear and Banished Knight Oleg can bail you out if it's too hard for ya. I'm still feeling torn in some aspects about the game though; no dragon in the game can match Midir from DS3 and I still think that balancing the game around spirit ashes make it preposterously difficult times, particularly against the likes of the infamous Malenia; but I guess there's already plenty of youtubers and and "letmesoloher" that have beaten her without any cheap tricks as well. All in all, a fantastic game, and well worth the money at $40-60. Can't wait for shadow of the erdtree

Never bothered reviewing a game before, but FromSoftware went above and beyond to craft a game that towers above the rest in scope, theme, mechanics, music, story and everything in (the lands) between. As frustratingly hard as some encounters may be, the prospect of discovering a new piece of lore, the flavor text on a dope item, a valuable upgrade, or parkour-ing your way to another hidden quest or boss, made me never waver in determination to see what was around the next corner.

Bravo.  This is one that will be remembered fondly for a long, long time. I Haven't felt like this about a game since the golden age of SquareSoft games.

161923047.review:
Obviously still very early impressions for how long of a game this is meant to be. I have explored a decent chunk of the starting area and have faced quite a few dungeon bosses now.

I have become a from software fan in the past couple of years, Having played first bloodborne and then sekiro - and now understand the joy that these games bring to many, including myself. I think Sekiro is one of the few 10/10 games I have ever played, and I could see myself potentially enjoying Elden Ring to that same level.

The worlds that from software are able to create never cease to amaze me. The atmosphere in this game immediately makes itself known with the big glowing tree you can see in the horizon pretty much all the time. The lore begs for you to learn more, and piece together the bits of information available. As for gameplay, fighting tree sentinel at level 1 was fun. Struck memories of gyobu in Sekiro. I can see why so many were upset at launch now, which makes it even funnier knowing I had to actively seek out his attention so he would start fighting me. The core of these games are all the same, Fight big bad over and over, learning everything about him until you know what he is going to do before even he knows. And using that information to punish them. Spirit ashes are a great optional addition to the game that are there for most optional bosses I've come across, although some boss are restricted in their use. These give you summons to help if you are new. This makes the game pretty newbie friendly, even if the boss move sets are sometimes annoying to deal with. Would recommend to anyone like me as a relatively new fan of these types of games that is still considering whether or not to buy, and would cautiously recommend to anyone looking to get into the franchise. I still think bloodborne is the easier game, but I can see the larger mass appeal in Elden Ring.

161917264.review:
It's actually amazing how many QoL things this game has that make it much more enjoyable than any other previous Souls-likes.

I'm not saying this is the best Souls-like, that is very much debatable, but things such as instant fast-travel (no item needed, nor it is unlocked late game or anything), Statues of Marika (no painful runbacks to bosses), clearing groups of enemies gives you back some healing flasks (just play the game aka beat enemies and explore), Spirit Ashes, the gentle guidance of grace, the map and NPCs being showed in, all of these things make the game more enjoyable so that you don't have to suffer through rather questionable design decision and just, you know, explore and beat bosses. And there's plenty more that I can't think of right now, and probably much more that need to be added. 

The game definitely doesn't need a traditional "difficulty slider" as the game mechanics can influence how hard or easy the game can be. Have a tough time with a boss or an area? Go somewhere else and level up a bit on easier enemies. Need just a bit more damage or something that can take aggro or tank? Summon spirit ashes. There's plenty of mechanics like this that you can opt in or out of in order to modify your experience to your liking.

Excellent bosses, impeccable lore and storytelling, various weaponry and armor (can't wait to check out new weapon types in the DLC), amazing locations, just a great game overall!
